newsitem.title: UK: Scotland's grains look good, weather worries muted.
newsitem.headline: Scotland's grains look good, weather worries muted.

text.p: Scotland's new cereals crop is developing well, with few of the weather worries which have affected parts of England and the western continent, farming experts around the country said.
"Currently we're doing very nicely thank-you," Dr David Cranstoun of the Scottish Agricultural College told Reuters.
"If anything this season we're a bit ahead of normal," he said, pointing out that Scottish grains are normally well behind their English counterparts.
Crops were looking well set up, but there was still a lot to play for.

There had been a period of dry weather, which came to an end over the weekend, with the arrival Sunday of colder, wet weather. The rain had been "just what we needed. We could probably do with a bit more." Cranstoun said.

"We haven't suffered as yet from drought," one co-op manager in the north of Scotland said. "There's been a reasonable start to spring. It's been warmer than normal and the crops are moving on apace," he said.
And even if there were a period without rain, Scotland was better placed than England to withstand it. "The water table is not particularly low. There's not the same potential for drought," he said.

Another co-op manager, further to the south and east, remarked on a different problem altogether. "Some of our winter crops look quite poor," he said. The reason was not obvious, but he put it down to early frost in October or November.
"Spring crops look quite good," he said. But there were concerns over depleted soil moisture reserves.
The area of wheat in Scotland is 107,000 hectares, according to the Scottish Office's December census.
This is 3.7 per cent up on the area a year earlier. The census covers crops sown by December 1, 1996.
The area of barley is up 22.9 per cent at 80,000 hectares. The area of oilseed rape is 6.0 per cent higher at 34,000 hectares.
